commander.name: Major-General Iven Giffard Mackay
commander.previous_service: WWI veteran - Gallipoli (1915), Western Front (1916-1918). Post-WWI: Australian militia commander. Distinguished record in both campaigns.

chief_of_staff.name: Colonel Frank Berryman
chief_of_staff.notes: Highly capable staff officer. Later promoted Major-General, distinguished service throughout Pacific War. Key figure in planning Operation Compass fortress assaults.

personnel_notes: Full-strength infantry division per 2nd AIF establishment. All-volunteer force enlisted for overseas service. Three infantry brigades (16th, 17th, 19th) each with three battalions (9 battalions total). Australian battalions larger than British equivalents (920 vs 800 personnel). Four rifle companies per battalion vs three in British formations. Higher proportion of skilled tradesmen and educated soldiers compared to British regular divisions. Average age 26 years (vs 21 in British divisions). Excellent morale - volunteers motivated by patriotism and adventure.

battalions.notes: Raised September 1939. First AIF battalion formed for WWII. Training in Palestine/Egypt Oct-Dec 1940.
Raised October 1939. Training Palestine/Egypt throughout Q4 1940.

brigades.notes: 16th Brigade completed training cycle Q4 1940. Intensive preparation for desert operations. Unit cohesion excellent by December. Designated as assault brigade for upcoming operations.
17th Brigade training status high by December 1940. Desert acclimatization complete. Brigadier Savige WWI veteran with exceptional tactical skill.

battalions.notes: Raised July 1940. Newest battalion - completed basic training, undergoing desert operations training Q4.

brigades.notes: 19th Brigade includes 2/11th Battalion (newest unit in division). Full operational capability achieved by late December 1940. Robertson later commanded I Australian Corps in Pacific.

infantry.notes: Australian infantry battalions organized with four rifle companies (A, B, C, D) vs three in British battalions. Each battalion: organic mortar platoon (8x 3-inch mortars), carrier platoon (13x Bren carriers), pioneer platoon, signals platoon, headquarters company. Total battalion strength 920 all ranks. Australian infantry doctrine emphasized aggressive patrolling, night operations, marksmanship, and physical fitness. Training throughout Q4 1940 focused on desert conditions, water discipline, navigation, combined arms coordination.

cavalry_reconnaissance.notes: Mechanized reconnaissance regiment. Equipped with Universal Carriers (Bren carriers), motorcycles, trucks. Light reconnaissance screens, flank security, advance guards. 8x 2-pdr anti-tank guns (portee-mounted) for self-defense. Training emphasized navigation, reporting, stealth.

machine_gun.notes: Sustained fire support battalion. 48x Vickers .303 heavy machine guns organized in four companies (12 Vickers each). Carrier-mounted for mobility. Barrage fire, defensive positions, fixed fire lanes. Critical for fortress assault support.

equipment.engineers_tools: full scale workshop and field equipment

pioneer.notes: Combat engineers with infantry training. Mine warfare (laying and clearing), obstacle construction and demolition, fortification, field defenses. Trained in Bangalore torpedoes for wire obstacle breaching. Essential for fortress assault operations.

signals.notes: Divisional communications network. Radio (wireless), telephone (field cables), dispatch riders. No. 11 wireless sets for brigade-division communications. No. 18 sets for battalion-brigade. Signals training emphasized reliability under combat conditions.

units.notes: Three batteries (8 guns each). Supporting 16th Brigade. Equipped with new 25-pounder gun-howitzers received Egypt 1940.
Three batteries. Supporting 17th Brigade. Fully trained and equipped by December 1940.
Three batteries. Supporting 19th Brigade. Combat-ready status achieved late Q4 1940.

field_artillery.ammunition_supply: Full establishment - 20 days basic load per gun. HE, AP, smoke rounds. Ammunition stocks built up in Egypt Oct-Dec 1940.
field_artillery.notes: Australian artillery doctrine emphasized aggressive forward deployment and concentrated fire. 25-pounder gun-howitzer dual-role weapon: indirect fire support (maximum range 12,250m) and direct fire anti-tank (AP shot effective to 900m vs light armor). Australian gunners many with pre-war militia artillery experience - highly trained. Fire control procedures practiced extensively during Q4 1940 training.

2pdr_qf.notes: Standard British/Commonwealth AT gun 1940. Effective vs Italian M11/39 (30mm armor) and M13/40 tanks. Some portee-mounted (truck bed) for rapid deployment.

anti_tank.organization: Four batteries, each 12 guns. Mix of towed and portee-mounted guns. Battery commanders trained in direct fire tactics.
anti_tank.notes: 2-pounder entered service 1938 as replacement for obsolete 25mm Hotchkiss. Effective anti-tank weapon in 1940-41 period. Could penetrate Italian M13/40 frontal armor (30mm) at normal engagement ranges (500-1000 yards). Portee mounting allowed rapid deployment and withdrawal - gun fired from truck bed or dismounted for static defense.

40mm_bofors.notes: Excellent light AA gun. Swedish design adopted by British Empire. Also effective vs ground targets (trucks, light armor, fortifications).

lewis_aa.notes: WWI-era Lewis guns on AA mounts. Light AA defense for columns and static positions. Limited effectiveness vs modern aircraft.

anti_aircraft.notes: Limited AA assets reflect lower Italian air threat in late 1940. Bofors guns excellent weapons - 40mm shells with proximity fuses. Dual-role capability: AA and ground support (bunker busting, vehicle destruction). Lewis guns obsolescent but still useful for light defense.

3inch.notes: Battalion-level indirect fire support. Each battalion had mortar platoon with 8x 3-inch mortars. HE and smoke rounds. Critical for close support beyond rifle/MG range.

2inch.allocation: 16 per battalion (approximate - one per platoon plus spares)
2inch.notes: Company/platoon level mortar. Smoke screening primary role. Limited HE capability. Light, portable (10.5 lbs), simple to operate.

tanks.notes: Infantry division with NO organic armor. Australian policy: no tank units in 2nd AIF divisions. Tank support provided by British Royal Tank Regiment units when required. During Operation Compass (Dec 1940 onward), 6th Australian Division supported by 7th Royal Tank Regiment with Matilda II infantry tanks for fortress assaults.

bedford_15cwt.notes: Bedford MW - standard British light truck. Reliable workhorse.

bedford_30cwt.notes: Bedford OYD - standard British medium truck. Primary infantry carrier.

ford_3ton.role: Heavy supplies, artillery prime movers, workshop support
ford_3ton.notes: Ford WOT series - heavy cargo and artillery towing.

chevrolet_30cwt.notes: Chevrolet C15 - Canadian-built, common in Commonwealth forces.

australian_built.notes: Locally-produced Australian vehicles supplementing British imports. Manufacturers: Holden, Ford Australia. Mix of utilities and light trucks.

trucks.notes: Full establishment motor transport for motorized infantry division. All infantry moved by truck (motorized, not mechanized). Vehicle establishment met by October 1940. Operational readiness high (95%) at end of Q4 due to recent delivery and limited operational wear. Desert conditions required enhanced maintenance - sand filters, cooling system upgrades, tire pressure adjustments. Workshops trained in desert vehicle maintenance throughout Q4.

carrier_machine_gun.role: Infantry support, ammunition resupply under fire, mobile firepower
carrier_machine_gun.notes: Infantry battalion carrier platoons (13 per battalion x 9 battalions = 117) plus machine gun battalion carriers (27)

carrier_scout.notes: Divisional cavalry regiment carriers for reconnaissance operations

carrier_3inch_mortar.notes: Battalion mortar platoon carriers for rapid mortar deployment

carrier_command.notes: Brigade and battalion command carriers with radio equipment

carrier_pioneer.role: Engineer support, obstacle clearing, mine warfare
carrier_pioneer.notes: Pioneer battalion carriers for combat engineer tasks

specifications.armor: 10-12mm (bulletproof only - no protection vs AT weapons)

carriers.notes: Universal Carriers critical to Australian tactics. Provided mobile firepower, reconnaissance capability, and protected resupply under fire. Lightly armored (small arms protection only). Highly maneuverable in desert terrain - excellent cross-country mobility. Australian doctrine: aggressive carrier employment for reconnaissance, flank security, rapid exploitation. Carriers often 'overloaded' with extra ammunition, water, crew. Mechanical reliability good in Q4 1940 (new equipment, limited wear).

norton_16h.notes: Norton 16H 500cc - standard British military motorcycle. Reliable, simple to maintain.

bsa_m20.notes: BSA M20 500cc - side-valve engine, highly reliable. Widely used throughout British forces.

norton_sidecar.notes: Norton with sidecar - additional cargo capacity, passenger capability. Used for signals work.

motorcycles.notes: Motorcycles critical for communications. Dispatch riders maintained contact between fast-moving units when radio unreliable or unavailable. Desert conditions challenging - sand, heat, mechanical reliability concerns. Riders trained in desert navigation using sun compass and dead reckoning.

staff_cars.role: Command and liaison vehicles for battalion, brigade, division HQs

ambulances.types: Austin K2 ambulance, Bedford ambulance conversions
ambulances.notes: Field ambulance companies equipped with dedicated ambulance vehicles plus general trucks for mass casualty scenarios

1.notes: Primary infantry weapon. SMLE (Short Magazine Lee-Enfield) - reliable, accurate, rapid-firing bolt-action rifle. Australian soldiers highly trained in marksmanship - many had civilian shooting experience (hunting, sport shooting). SMLE's 10-round magazine and smooth bolt action gave Australian infantry high sustained firepower. Known as 'the finest bolt-action rifle ever made.' Effective to 550 yards with iron sights.

2.allocation: 2 per platoon (40 men), 8 per company (120 men), 32 per battalion (920 men), plus carrier platoon and HQ company extras. Total ~64 per battalion x 9 battalions = 576, plus divisional troops = 580 total.
2.notes: Excellent light machine gun. Czechoslovak design (ZB vz. 26) manufactured under license in Britain. Reliable, accurate, easy to maintain. Provided squad/section automatic fire. Australian platoons organized around two Bren gun sections. Gun bipod-mounted for stability. Quick-change barrel for sustained fire. Interchangeable parts throughout British Empire forces.

specifications.effective_range: 2,000 yards direct fire, 4,500 yards indirect fire
specifications.weight: 40 lbs (gun only), 50 lbs with water and tripod

3.organization: 2/2nd Machine Gun Battalion - 48 guns total organized in four companies (12 guns each). Company typically attached to infantry brigade for operations.
3.notes: Sustained fire support weapon. Water-cooled jacket enabled continuous fire for hours without barrel change. Used for defensive positions, fixed fire lanes, barrage fire (indirect fire over own troops onto enemy positions). Indirect fire capability to 4,500 yards using dial sight and range tables. Extremely reliable - 'Queen of the Battlefield.' WWI-proven design still highly effective in 1940.

QF_25_pounder.organization: Three field regiments (2/1st, 2/2nd, 2/3rd) with 24 guns each
QF_25_pounder.notes: Ordnance QF 25-pounder Mk II - excellent gun-howitzer. Maximum range 12,250m. HE, AP, smoke rounds. Dual-role: indirect fire support and direct fire anti-tank.

QF_2_pounder.organization: 6th Australian Anti-Tank Regiment - four batteries of 12 guns each
QF_2_pounder.notes: Ordnance QF 2-pounder - standard British/Commonwealth AT gun 1940-42. Effective vs Italian armor.

Bofors_40mm.notes: Bofors 40mm L/60 - excellent light AA gun, dual-role AA/ground support

Lewis_AA.notes: Lewis Gun on AA mount - light AA defense, obsolescent but still useful

3_inch_mortar.notes: Ordnance ML 3-inch - battalion-level support, 8 per battalion

2_inch_mortar.notes: Ordnance ML 2-inch - company/platoon level, primarily smoke screening

air_support_notes: No organic air assets. Air support provided by RAF Western Desert Air Force (separate command). Close air support doctrine still developing in 1940. Coordination through RAF liaison officers at division HQ.

supply_logistics.supply_status: Excellent - newly deployed division with full establishment. Build-up of ammunition, fuel, water, rations completed by December 1940 in preparation for offensive operations. Supply dumps established at Mersa Matruh area. Division required ~400 tons/day for sustained operations (rations, ammunition, fuel, water, maintenance stores). Supply lines from Alexandria via Mersa Matruh secure and functioning well. No operational constraints from supply shortages in Q4 1940.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal Egypt/Libya border - coastal plain, rocky desert, escarpments

subordinate_units.notes: NSW/Victoria battalions. Assault brigade for Operation Compass.
Victoria/South Australia battalions. Second assault wave capability.
Western Australia/Victoria battalions. Reserve and exploitation role.
Three field artillery regiments supporting division.
Mechanized reconnaissance with carriers and trucks.

tactical_doctrine.role: Infantry assault division - preparation for Operation Compass offensive against Italian 10th Army. Training focus: fortress assault, combined arms operations, desert warfare.
special_capabilities: High morale and unit cohesion (volunteer force)
Physical fitness and endurance (average age 26, excellent condition)
tactical_innovations: Four-company battalion structure (vs British three-company) providing greater tactical flexibility
Aggressive use of Bren carriers for mobile firepower and rapid movement
Night approach marches followed by dawn assaults (trained Oct-Dec 1940)
Combined arms coordination between infantry, artillery, engineers (practiced extensively)
Desert navigation techniques using sun compass, star navigation, dead reckoning
Water discipline and conservation procedures (critical for desert operations)
known_issues: No combat experience - division untested in battle as of December 1940
Limited tank cooperation training (no organic armor, reliance on attached British tanks)
Desert conditions unfamiliar to Australian troops (trained primarily in Palestine Q4)
Vehicle maintenance challenges in sand and heat (learning curve)
Air-ground coordination doctrine still developing (limited RAF liaison training)
2/11th Battalion newest unit (formed July 1940) - less training time than other battalions
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Q4 1940 training focused on desert acclimatization. Water discipline emphasized - ration reduced from 15 liters/day theoretical to 4-5 liters/day practical. Navigation training using sun compass and landmarks. Vehicle modifications: enhanced air filters, cooling system adjustments, sand tires. Uniform adaptations: light khaki drill uniforms, wide-brimmed hats (slouch hat retained). Equipment modifications: camouflage nets for desert, water containers (jerry cans, canteens), sand-colored paint for vehicles. Medical training: heat exhaustion prevention, desert sores treatment, dysentery prevention.

scenario_suitability: Training scenarios - infantry assault on fortified positions
Water discipline and desert survival scenarios
special_rules: All-Volunteer Force - High morale and motivation (+1 to morale checks)
Excellent Marksmanship - Australian rifle training emphasis (+1 to small arms accuracy)
Physical Fitness - Average age 26, excellent condition (+1 to endurance/fatigue checks)
Untested in Combat - No battle experience as of December 1940 (first combat January 1941)
Four-Company Battalions - Greater tactical flexibility vs British three-company structure
Desert Acclimatization Complete - Training in Palestine/Egypt Oct-Dec 1940 (no penalties for heat/desert)
Limited Tank Coordination - No organic armor, minimal training with British tanks (penalties for combined arms until experience gained)
historical_engagements: None in Q4 1940 - Division in training and preparation phase
Deployed to Western Desert Force December 1940
Operation Compass begins 9 December 1940 (very end of quarter)
First combat: Battle of Bardia (3-5 January 1941, Q1 1941)

source: Australian War Memorial - 6th Division formation and deployment to Middle East
Australian War Memorial - 2nd AIF unit war diaries October-December 1940
Barton Maughan - Tobruk and El Alamein (Australia in the War of 1939-1945, Series One - Army, Volume III)
Gavin Long - To Benghazi (Australia in the War of 1939-1945, Series One - Army, Volume I)
6th Australian Division Association - Unit histories and veterans accounts
British 1941-Q1 6th Australian Division JSON (forward reference for consistency)
British 1940-Q4 Western Desert Force JSON (parent formation context)
Australian Army - 2nd AIF divisional establishments and tables of organization
Imperial War Museum - Australian forces Middle East 1940
Commonwealth War Graves Commission - 6th Division personnel records
known_gaps: Exact vehicle operational readiness percentages (95% estimated based on new equipment status)
Precise ammunition stockpile quantities (20 days estimated from standard establishments)
2/11th Battalion exact training status December 1940 (newest battalion, formed July 1940)
Detailed RAF liaison procedures (air-ground cooperation doctrine still developing 1940)
Exact water consumption rates during training (4.5 liters/day estimated from later operational data)
validation.data_quality_notes: High-quality historical documentation from Australian War Memorial official histories. Personnel total (16,800) based on 2nd AIF divisional establishment: 9 infantry battalions (920 each = 8,280) + divisional troops (2,160) + artillery (2,620) + medical/supply/ordnance (1,160) + HQ (405) + reserves/attachments (1,975). Equipment totals based on Australian divisional establishments 1940 with British equipment allocations. 72x 25-pounder field guns confirmed from multiple sources (3 regiments x 24 guns). 48x 2-pounder AT guns standard divisional establishment. Ground vehicles total (2,219) calculated from establishment tables and confirmed against similar British/Commonwealth divisions. No combat operations in Q4 1940 - division in training phase. Confidence: 85% due to excellent Australian official history documentation, clear establishment tables, but limited detailed records of specific equipment serial numbers and exact training schedules.

historical_notes.formation_deployment: 6th Australian Division formed September-October 1939 as first division of 2nd Australian Imperial Force (2nd AIF). Volunteer expeditionary force for WWII service. Departed Australia January-February 1940. Arrived Palestine February-March 1940. Training in Palestine April-November 1940. Moved to Egypt November-December 1940 for operational deployment. Assigned to Western Desert Force (later XIII Corps) December 1940 replacing 4th Indian Division (transferred to Sudan for East African Campaign).
historical_notes.command: Major-General Iven Giffard Mackay commanded from formation (October 1939) through Operation Compass and Greece campaign (April 1941). Highly regarded commander - WWI veteran (Gallipoli, Western Front), methodical planner, concerned for troop welfare. Promoted Lieutenant-General May 1942. Colonel Frank Berryman (Chief of Staff) exceptional staff officer, later Major-General in Pacific War. Brigade commanders: Boase (16th), Savige (17th), Robertson (19th) all proven leaders.
historical_notes.2nd_aif_context: 2nd AIF organized as all-volunteer force separate from Australian Militia (home defense forces). Volunteers enlisted for duration of war, overseas service. Higher educational levels and skilled trades representation vs conscript forces. Average age 26 years (mature soldiers vs 21 in British divisions). Strong unit cohesion - state-based recruiting (battalions from same Australian states). Excellent morale - patriotic motivation, adventure, desire to emulate 1st AIF (WWI Anzacs).
historical_notes.training_q4_1940: October-November: Final training in Palestine - live fire exercises, tactical problems, physical conditioning. Late November: Movement to Egypt, concentration Mersa Matruh area. December: Desert acclimatization training, combined arms exercises with British units, preparation for Operation Compass. Night operations practiced extensively. Fortress assault tactics developed with British planners. No combat in Q4 1940. Operation Compass began 9 December 1940 (final days of quarter) - 6th Division held in reserve initially, committed to Bardia assault January 1941.
historical_notes.equipment_status: Fully equipped by October 1940. Personal weapons (rifles, Brens, Vickers) British manufacture, excellent quality. Vehicles mostly British (Bedford, Ford) with some Canadian (Chevrolet) and Australian-built supplements. 25-pounder guns brand new - received in Egypt mid-1940. Universal Carriers (Bren carriers) full establishment. Vehicle operational readiness high (95%) due to new equipment, limited operational wear. Ammunition stocks built up throughout Q4 in preparation for offensive. Water and rations stockpiled at Mersa Matruh.
historical_notes.significance: 6th Australian Division would become one of the elite assault formations of Operation Compass. Three fortress assaults in six weeks (Bardia, Tobruk, Benghazi) established division's formidable reputation. In Q4 1940, division was untested but superbly trained and equipped. Volunteer ethos, high morale, excellent physical conditioning, and thorough training produced outstanding combat effectiveness when committed to battle (January 1941 onward).
